header_1: H5N1 in Wild birds in Russia
content_1: Eighteen blood samples from migratory birds in the Altai territories have tested positive for antibodies to H5. According to the Russian agriculture department, the presence of antibodies means that “the birds have been in contact with infected birds or have survived avian influenza, but they are not a source of infection.”
content_2: No new reports this week.H5N1 in Humans
content_3: A 16-month-old boy is the first human H5N1 case reported in Bangladesh, the director of the Institute of Epidemiology and Disease Control and Research in Dhaka said. The boy's infection, which occurred in January, was only detected during a routine check-up; he has since recovered. He lives in a poor district of Dhaka and was exposed to live and slaughtered chickens around his home. H5N1 was first reported in Bangladesh in March 2006 and has since spread to 47 of the country’s 64 districts. "When a disease is so widespread in poultry, it is really a matter of time before you get a human case. It shows the need to control the disease in animals if you are going to reduce the chances of transmission to humans," said WHO spokesman Gregory Hartl. (more...)
